pullRequest.body:
This PR adds the types and lemmas for oracle-based computation. In this model, computations are run on a monad which also counts the number of oracle queries executed. With it, it becomes possible to reason about the upper bound of the query complexity of algorithms. In the future, we could extend this work to include the necessary bits from information theory and probability to also reason about lower bounds on query complexity, like the work in https://github.com/girving/debate.

Zulip discussion: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2318629.20runtime.20complexity.20of.20sorting.20a.20list

Co-authored-by: Geoffrey Irving <irving@naml.us>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

nodes.body:
I got some significant simplifications out of replacing the two `Comp` arguments here with `Bool  Comp`. It practice it seems to reduce the number of cases needed in proofs.

See recent https://github.com/girving/debate for the new style.
Per previous comment, using `Bool  Comp` in the definition of `query'` replaces the if with `(f x).run os`, which is cleaner.
Just "after execution" ("it's" is both wrong and unnecessary).
No need for parentheses around `o i y` (but also this if will go away once you do the `Bool  Comp` thing).
I think this one should be `simp` too.
Unless there are obstructions to doing so, `Type*` would probably be a good idea throughout

What do you think of something much more dependently-typed, like this?
```lean
/-- `Comp   s ` is the type of ``-producing computations that have access to a family of `oracles i : (a :  i)   a` restricted by `i  s`. -/
inductive Comp {I : Type*} ( : I  Type*) ( : {i : I}   i  Type*) (s : Set I) ( : Type*) : Type _ where
  /-- A pure value without an oracle computation. -/
  | pure :   Comp   s 
  /-- An invocation of the permitted oracle `o` with input `a`, and a way to proceed with computation for each possible return value. -/
  | query (o : I) (ho : o  s) (a :  o) : ( a  Comp   s )  Comp   s 

/-- A sorting computation has access to an oracle that can decide the relation between two elements. -/
abbrev SortingComp {} (r :     Prop) := Comp (fun _ : Unit =>   ) (fun ab => Decidable (r ab.1 ab.2))
```

This has two main benefits over your version:
* It lets us have oracles that decide non-binary decisions
* It gives the continuation access to a proof that the decision was correct.
I agree that making the output flexible is good! Ill make this change to my https://github.com/girving/debate version as well.

It's also not clear to me whether we need a family of oracles, or if a single oracle would suffice; after all, you can have an oracle that takes a sigma type and uses `.fst` to decide which suboracle to call.

This makes `cost` slightly more complicated, but if the cost were configurable per-query, rather than a constant `1`, I think you can still encode the same things.

It's not entirely clear to me what purpose `s` serves in `Comp` (which is the reason for these existing); as far as I can tell, the sorting stuff does not need it.

@girving, do you have an example in mind where this is useful, vs just changing the indexing type of `I` if a different set of oracles is wanted?

Heres how its used in the debate protocol: https://github.com/girving/debate/blob/d3e2d0bb7f6f450bb3899fb349a69133329541eb/Debate/Protocol.lean#L94

And without it, this theorem and similar wouldnt be true, as an evil Bob could query Alices oracle: https://github.com/girving/debate/blob/d3e2d0bb7f6f450bb3899fb349a69133329541eb/Debate/Cost.lean#L55

I should say Im sympathetic to the worry that this is too specific to one kind of formalized result. We dont need it for sort, so stripping it would be fine if we just want to get sort into mathlib (my lower bound on sort doesnt use this either, of course).

The alternative I'm proposing in that example is for Bob, Alice, and Vera to have different indexing types. So for instance, your `def step` would have indexing type `BobUnit  AliceUnit  VeraUnit`.

Of course, this then becomes tricky to plumb combining together the oracles...

Ah, interesting. So the set argument to
Comp goes away, and cost takes a set of queries to count across.

pullRequest.title: feat(Computability/QueryComplexity): Oracle-based computation

source.title: feat(Computability/QueryComplexity/Sort.lean): Formalization of upper bound of queries for merge sort
